Chapter on Pure Conduct, Part 8, Section 4
Furthermore, good sons!
What is meant by the fact that while all worldly beings do not know, see, or realize it, the bodhisattvas do know, see, and realize it?
It refers to the six recollections.
What are the six?
Recollecting the Buddha, recollecting the Dharma, recollecting the Saá¹ƒgha, recollecting the precepts, recollecting giving, and recollecting the heavens.
Good sons!
What is meant by recollecting the Buddha?
The TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One with Qualities, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the World,
The Unsurpassed One, the Trainer and Tamer of Men, the Teacher of Gods and Men, the Buddha, the World-Honored One, is always
unchanging. He is fully endowed with the ten powers, the four fearlessnesses, and the great lion's roar. He is called the

Great Åšramaá¹‡a, the Great BrÄhmaá¹‡a, the Great Pure One, who has ultimately reached the other shore, the one who isğŸ”½unconquerable, the one whose crown cannot be seen, the one who is fearless, unstartled, and unmoved, the one who is
alone and without a companion,
self-enlightenment without a teacher, swift wisdom, great wisdom, sharp wisdom, profound wisdom, wisdom of liberation,
unshared wisdom, all-pervading wisdom, ultimate wisdom, accomplishment of the treasure of wisdom,
elephant king among men, bull king among men, dragon king among men, great man among men,
lotus among men, pundarika flower, tamer of men, teacher, great giver, great Dharma
teacher, known as a great Dharma teacher because of knowing the Dharma, known as a great Dharma teacher because of knowing the meaning,
known as a great Dharma teacher because of knowing the time, known as a great Dharma teacher because of knowing contentment,

known as a great Dharma teacher because of knowing the self, known as a great Dharma teacher because of knowing the great assembly, known as a great Dharma teacher because of knowing the various natures of sentient beings, known as a great Dharma teacher because of knowing the sharpness and dullness of faculties,
known as a great Dharma teacher because of expounding the middle way.
What is meant by TathÄgata?
It means not changing from what was spoken by the Buddhas of the past.
How is it unchanging?
The buddhas of the past, in order to deliver sentient beings, expounded the twelve divisions of the canon. The TathÄgata is also like this, and is therefore called the TathÄgata.

The buddhas, the world-honored ones, come to great nirvÄá¹‡a from the six perfections, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, and the eleven kinds of emptiness. The TathÄgata is also like this. Therefore, the Buddha is called the TathÄgata.

The buddhas, the world-honored ones, in order to deliver sentient beings, skillfully reveal the three vehicles. Their lifespans are immeasurable and incalculable. The TathÄgata is also like this. Therefore, the Buddha is called the TathÄgata.
What is meant by 'worthy'?
Worldly dharmas are all called enemies. The Buddha should destroy them, and is therefore called 'worthy'.
The four demons are the enemies of the bodhisattvas. When the buddhas, the tathÄgatas, were bodhisattvas, they were able to use wisdom to destroy the four demons. Therefore, he is called 'worthy'.
Furthermore, Arhat means to be far removed. When one is a bodhisattva, one should be far removed from innumerable afflictions, and therefore it is called Arhat.

Furthermore, Arhat means to delight. The Buddhas of the past, when they were bodhisattvas, although for innumerable eons they endured various sufferings and afflictions for the sake of sentient beings, they never felt unhappy, but always delighted in it. The TathÄgata is also like this, and therefore it is called Arhat.
Moreover, Arhat means that all humans and gods should make offerings with various fragrances, flowers, necklaces, banners, canopies, music, and so forth. Therefore, it is called Arhat.
What is Samyak-Saá¹ƒbuddha (Perfectly Enlightened One)?
Samyak means not inverted, and Saá¹ƒbuddha means to thoroughly penetrate the four inversions.
Moreover, Samyak means to practice austerities, and Saá¹ƒbuddha means to know that the result of suffering definitely arises from the cause of practicing austerities.
Moreover, 'correct' means knowing the world, and 'omniscient' means definitively knowing the cultivation of the middle way to attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
Moreover, 'correct' means countable, measurable, and comparable, while 'omniscient' means uncountable, immeasurable, and incomparable. Therefore, the Buddha is called the Correctly Omniscient One.
Good man!
ÅšrÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas have both omniscience and non-omniscience.
Why is this?
Omniscience means the five aggregates, twelve sense fields, and eighteen elements, which Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas also attain omniscience about, which is called omniscience.
Why is it non-omniscience?
Good man!
Even if the two vehicles contemplated one form aggregate for innumerable eons, they would not be able to fully know it. For this reason, Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas do not have omniscience.
What is meant by 'one of right and universal knowledge'?
Illumination is called attaining immeasurable good fruits, and practice is called feet. Good fruits are called anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
Feet are called precepts and wisdom. Riding on the feet of precepts and wisdom, one attains anuttara-samyak-sambodhi. Therefore, it is called illumination and practice complete.
Moreover, illumination is called mantra, practice is called auspicious, and complete is called fruit. Good man!
This is called the meaning of the world;
Mantra is called liberation, auspicious is called anuttara-samyak-sambodhi, and fruit is called great parinirvÄá¹‡a. Therefore, it is called illumination and practice complete.
Moreover, illumination is called light, practice is called karma, and complete is called fruit. Good man!
This is called the meaning of the world;
Light is called non-negligence, karma is called the six pÄramitÄs, and fruit is called anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
Furthermore, bright refers to the three kinds of brightness:
First, the brightness of bodhisattvas; second, the brightness of buddhas; third, the brightness of non-brightness.

The brightness of bodhisattvas is prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, the brightness of buddhas is the buddha eye, and the brightness of non-brightness is ultimate emptiness. The practitioner, for the sake of sentient beings for immeasurable eons, cultivates all wholesome actions, and the bright one clearly sees buddha-nature. For this reason, it is called bright and accomplished in practices.
What is meant by 'well-gone'?
Well is called high, and gone is called not high. Good sons!
This is called the meaning of the mundane world;
High is called anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, and not high is the mind of the TathÄgata.
Good sons!
If the mind is high, it is not called the TathÄgata. Therefore, the TathÄgata is called well-gone.
Moreover, well is called a good and virtuous friend, and gone is the fruition of a good and virtuous friend. Good sons!
This is called the meaning of the mundane world;

A good and virtuous friend is the initial arousal of the mind of enlightenment, and the fruition is called great parinirvÄá¹‡a. The TathÄgata does not abandon the initial arousal of the mind of enlightenment and attains great parinirvÄá¹‡a, and therefore the TathÄgata is called the Well-Gone One.
Moreover, good means excellent, and gone means existent. Good sons!
This is called the meaning of the mundane world;
excellent means seeing the Buddha-nature, and existent means great parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Good sons!
The nature of parinirvÄá¹‡a is actually not existent. The buddhas, the world-honored ones, because of the mundane world, say that it exists.
Good sons!

It is just like worldly people who actually have no children but say they have children, and who actually have no path but say they have a path. ParinirvÄá¹‡a is also like this. Because of the mundane world, it is said to exist. The buddhas, the world-honored ones, attain great parinirvÄá¹‡a, and therefore they are called the Well-Gone Ones.
Good sons!
What is meant by understanding the world?
Good sons!
World refers to the five aggregates. Understanding means knowing. The World-Honored Buddhas skillfully understand the five aggregates, thus called understanding the world.
Moreover, world refers to the five desires. Understanding means non-attachment. Because of non-attachment to the five desires, it is called understanding the world.

Moreover, understanding the world means that in the innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeya worlds in the east, all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas do not know, see, or understand, but all Buddhas fully know, see, and understand. In the south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above and below, it is the same. Therefore, the Buddha is called understanding the world.

Moreover, world refers to all ordinary beings. Understanding means knowing the good and evil causes and effects of all ordinary beings, which is not known by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, but only known by the Buddha. Therefore, the Buddha is called understanding the world.
Moreover, world refers to the lotus flower. Understanding means non-defilement. Good man!
This is called the meaning of the world;
The lotus flower is the TathÄgata. Not defiled means that the TathÄgata is not tainted by the eight worldly dharmas of the world. Therefore, the Buddha is called the Knower of the World.
Moreover, the Knower of the World means that the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are called the Knower of the World.
Why is it so?
Because the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas see the world, they are called the Knower of the World.
Good man!
Just as because of food one obtains life, food is called life,
the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are also like this. Because they see the world, they are called the Knower of the World.

What is the Unsurpassed Person?ğŸ”½The unsurpassed person is called the one who has nothing to cut off. The one who has nothing to cut off is called the unsurpassed person. The Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, have no afflictions, so there is nothing to cut off. Therefore, the Buddha is called the Unsurpassed Person.
Moreover, the unsurpassed person is called the one who disputes. The unsurpassed person has no disputes. The TathÄgata has no disputes. Therefore, the Buddha is called the Unsurpassed Person.

Moreover, the superior person is called one whose words can be destroyed, while the unsurpassed person's words cannot be destroyed. The TathÄgata's words cannot be destroyed by any sentient being, and therefore the Buddha is called the unsurpassed person.

Moreover, the superior person is called the superior seat, while the unsurpassed person is called the unsurpassed seat. There is no one surpassing the buddhas of the three times, and therefore the Buddha is called the unsurpassed person.
Superior means new, and person means old. The buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, embody the great nirvÄá¹‡a, which is neither new nor old. Therefore, the Buddha is called the unsurpassed person.
What is meant by 'tamer of men'?
One who is already a man also tames men.
Good man!
The TathÄgata is truly neither a man nor not a man. Because he tames men, the TathÄgata is called a man.
Good man!
All men and women, if they possess four dharmas, are called men.
What are the four?
First, a good and virtuous friend; second, the ability to listen to the Dharma; third, contemplation of the meaning; fourth, practice in accordance with the teachings.
Good man!
If a man or woman possesses these four dharmas, they are called a true man.
Good man!
If a man does not have these four dharmas, he cannot be called a true man. Why is this?
Although his body is that of a man, his actions are the same as those of an animal.
The TathÄgata tames men and women, and for this reason he is called the Buddha, the Tamer of Men.
Furthermore, good man!
There are four kinds of horse tamers:
The first touches the hair, the second touches the skin, the third touches the flesh, and the fourth touches the bone, and they all do as the rider intends.
The TathÄgata is also like this. He tames sentient beings with four kinds of dharmas:
First, he speaks of birth, causing them to accept the Buddha's words, like touching their hair, and they do as the rider intends.

If one speaks of birth and old age, one will accept the Buddha's words, like a hair-touching skin that follows the driver's intention.ğŸ”½If one speaks of birth, old age, and sickness, one will accept the Buddha's words, like a hair-touching skin and flesh that follows the driver's intention.
If one speaks of birth, old age, sickness, and death, one will accept the Buddha's words, like a hair-touching skin, flesh, and bones that follow the driver's intention.
Good man!
The driver taming a horse is not definite, but the Tathagata World-Honored One taming sentient beings is definitely not false. Therefore, the Buddha is called the Tamer of Men.
Why is he called the Teacher of Gods and Humans?
There are two kinds of teachers:
one is a good teacher, and the other is a bad teacher.
The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas always teach sentient beings with good dharmas.
What are the good dharmas?
They are the goodness of body, speech, and mind.
The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas teach sentient beings, saying:
'Good men, you should stay far away from the unwholesome actions of the body.
Why is this?
Because physical evil karma can be abandoned and liberation attained, therefore I teach you this Dharma.
If evil karma could not be abandoned and liberation attained, I would never teach you to abandon it.

If sentient beings, having abandoned evil karma, were to fall into the three evil destinies, there would be no such case. Because of abandonment, they accomplish supreme perfect enlightenment and attain great nirvana.
Therefore, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas always use this Dharma to teach and transform sentient beings. The same is true for speech and mind. Therefore, the Buddha is called the unsurpassed teacher.
Furthermore, in the past he had not yet attained the Way, but now he has attained it. He uses the Way he has attained to teach sentient beings;
From the beginning, he had not yet cultivated pure conduct, but now he has completed it. He uses what he has cultivated to teach sentient beings;
He himself destroys ignorance and also helps sentient beings destroy ignorance;
Having attained pure vision oneself, one also removes the blindness and confusion of sentient beings, enabling them to attain pure vision;
Knowing the two truths oneself, one also expounds the two truths for sentient beings.
Having attained liberation oneself, one also speaks the Dharma of liberation for sentient beings;
Having crossed the great river of birth and death without limit oneself, one also enables sentient beings to all attain liberation;
Having attained fearlessness oneself, one also teaches sentient beings to be free from fear;
Having attained nirvana oneself, one also expounds the great nirvana for sentient beings;
Therefore, the Buddha is called the unsurpassed teacher.
Tian means day. In heaven, the days are long and the nights are short, so it is called tian.
Moreover, tian means being without sorrow or distress, always experiencing bliss, so it is called tian.
Moreover, tian means lamplight, able to destroy darkness and become great illumination, so it is called tian.
It is also because one is able to destroy the darkness of evil karma, attain good karma, and be born in the heavens, so it is called tian.
Moreover, 'tian' means auspicious, because of auspiciousness, it is called 'tian'.
Moreover, 'tian' is called 'sun', because of having light, it is called 'tian'.
For this reason, it is called 'tian'.

'Ren' means being able to be greatly kind and righteous, moreover, 'ren' means having a soft body and speech, moreover, 'ren' means having arrogance, moreover, 'ren' means being able to destroy arrogance.
Good man!
Although the Buddhas are the unsurpassed great teachers for all sentient beings, the sÅ«tras say they are teachers of gods and humans.
Why is it so?
Good man!

Among all sentient beings, only gods and humans are able to give rise to the mind of supreme perfect enlightenment, able to cultivate the ten wholesome courses of action, able to attain the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, arhatship, pratyekabuddhahood, and supreme perfect enlightenment. Therefore, the Buddha is called the teacher of gods and humans.
What is meant by Buddha?
Buddha means enlightened. Having awakened oneself, one is also able to awaken others.
Good man!
It is like a person who is aware of the presence of a thief, and the thief is unable to do anything.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to be aware of all immeasurable afflictions. Having become aware of them, they cause the afflictions to be unable to do anything. Therefore, they are called Buddhas.
Because of this awareness, they do not give rise to birth, old age, sickness, or death. Therefore, they are called Buddhas.
BhagavÄn means bhagavÄn. BhagavÄn means able to destroy afflictions. Because they are able to destroy afflictions, they are called bhagavÄns.

Moreover, because they are able to accomplish all wholesome dharmas, because they are able to skillfully understand the meanings of all dharmas, because they possess great merit and virtue that cannot be surpassed, because their great fame and renown extends in all ten directions, because they are able to bestow great wisdom in various ways, and because they have eliminated the female faculty for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas.
Good man!

Whether male or female, if one is able to contemplate the Buddha in this way, whether walking, standing, sitting, lying down, day or night, light or dark, one will always be able to see the World-Honored Buddha without fail.
Good man!
Why is he called the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, up to the BhagavÄn, and has such immeasurable merits and great fame?
Good man!

In the past, for innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva respected his parents, preceptors, teachers, elders, and seniors. For innumerable kalpas, he always practiced giving for the sake of sentient beings, upheld the precepts, cultivated patience, diligently practiced vigor, meditation, wisdom, great kindness, great compassion, great joy, and great equanimity. For this reason, he has now attained the thirty-two marks, the eighty minor marks, and the vajra body.

Moreover, the bodhisattva cultivated the faculties of faith, mindfulness, vigor, concentration, and wisdom for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas in the past, and with respect and offerings to teachers and elders, always sought the benefits of the Dharma, not the benefits of food.

If the bodhisattva upholds the twelve divisions of the scriptures, recites and chants them, it is always for the sake of sentient beings to attain liberation, peace, and happiness, never for his own sake.
Why is this?
The bodhisattva always cultivates the mind of transcending the world, the mind of leaving the household life, the mind of non-action, the mind of non-dispute,
the mind of non-defilement, the mind of non-bondage, the mind of non-attachment, the mind of non-obstruction,
the mind of non-indeterminate, the mind of non-birth and death, the mind of non-doubt, the mind of non-greed,
the mind of non-hatred, the mind of non-delusion, the mind of non-arrogance, the mind of non-turbidity,
the mind of non-affliction, the mind of non-suffering, the mind of immeasurability, the mind of vastness,
empty mind, no mind, neither mind nor no mind, disciplined mind, unguarded mind, concealed mind,
worldly mind, always concentrated mind, always cultivated mind, always liberated mind,
mind without retribution, mind without vows, well-vowed mind, unmistaken mind, gentle mind,
unwavering mind, autonomous mind, immaculate mind, ultimate truth mind, irreversible
mind, impermanent mind, upright mind, unpretentious mind, pure good mind, mind without
much or little, mind without hardness, mind without ordinary beings, mind without Å›rÄvakas,
mind without pratyekabuddhas, well-knowing the realm of mind, knowing the realm of mind's arising, knowing the realm of mind's abiding,
knowing the realm of mind's autonomy, therefore now attaining the ten powers, four fearlessnesses, great compassion,
three establishments of mindfulness, permanence, bliss, self, and purity, therefore attaining the title of TathÄgata up to BhagavÄn,
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's mindfulness of the Buddha.
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's mindfulness of the Dharma?
Good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva contemplates the Dharma that is spoken by the Buddhas as being the most wonderful and supreme. Because of this Dharma, it enables sentient beings to attain present results.
Only this true Dharma has no time period. It is seen by the Dharma eye, not by the flesh eye.
It cannot be compared with analogies. It does not arise, does not emerge, does not abide, does not cease,

does not begin, does not end, is unconditioned, is innumerable. For those without a dwelling, it creates a dwelling. For those without refuge, it creates a refuge. For those in darkness, it creates illumination. For those who have not reached the other shore, it enables them to reach the other shore.
For those without fragrance, it creates unobstructed fragrance. It is invisible, immovable, untransformed,
not long, not short. It permanently severs all pleasures and is the bliss of peace. It is ultimately subtle, not
Cutting off form while also being form, up to cutting off consciousness while also being consciousness,

while also being realms, not cutting off existence while also being existence, not cutting off entrances while also being entrances,
not cutting off causes while also being causes, not cutting off effects while also being effects,

not ceasing, permanently free from arising and ceasing while also being cessation, not characteristics, not not characteristics, cutting off

all characteristics while also being characteristics, not teaching, not not teaching while also being the teacher, not fear, not peace,ğŸ”½cutting off all fears while also being peace, not patience, not not patience, permanently cutting off impatience
while also being patience, not stopping, not not stopping, cutting off all stopping while also being stopping,
The summit of all dharmas, able to permanently sever all afflictions, pure and without characteristics, forever

liberated from all characteristics, the ultimate abode of innumerable sentient beings, able to extinguish the blazing fire of all birth and death,ğŸ”½this is the place where the buddhas dwell, always unchanging. This is called
the bodhisattva's mindfulness of the Dharma.
What is meant by mindfulness of the Saá¹…gha?

The noble Saá¹…gha of the buddhas abides in accordance with the Dharma, receives the upright Dharma, and practices in accordance with it. It cannot be seen, grasped, destroyed, harmed, or conceived of. It is the excellent field of merit for all sentient beings.

Although it is a field of merit, it does not accept anything. It is pure, undefiled, without outflows, unconditioned, vast and boundless. Its mind is disciplined and gentle, equal and non-dual, without agitation or turbidity, and always unchanging. This is called mindfulness of the Saá¹…gha.
What is meant by mindfulness of precepts?

Bodhisattvas contemplate that having precepts is not breaking, not leaking, not decaying, not mixed, although without form and color, it can be guarded and upheld, although without contact, skillfully cultivating expedient means, it can be fully possessed, without fault, praised by buddhas and bodhisattvas, it is the cause of the great vehicle and great nirvana.
Good sons!

It is like the great earth, a ship, a necklace, a great clan, the great ocean, lye, a house, a sword, a bridge, a good doctor's wonderful medicine, agada medicine, a wish-fulfilling jewel, feet, eyes, parents, a shady place, which cannot be robbed by thieves, cannot be harmed, fire cannot burn it, water cannot float it away.

It is like a great mountain staircase, the wonderful jewel victory banner of buddhas and bodhisattvas. If one abides in this precept, one attains the fruit of stream-entry, and I also have a share in it, but I do not need it.
Why is it so?
If I attain this fruit of stream-entry, I will not be able to extensively deliver all sentient beings.
If I abide by this precept, I will attain supreme perfect enlightenment, and I will also have a share in it, which is what I desire.
Why is it so?
If I attain supreme perfect enlightenment, I will extensively expound the wonderful Dharma for the sake of sentient beings and act as their refuge.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's mindfulness of precepts.
What is mindfulness of giving?

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva deeply observes that this giving is the cause of supreme perfect enlightenment. The buddhas and bodhisattvas closely cultivate such giving, and I also closely cultivate it in the same way. If I do not give generously, I will not be able to adorn the fourfold assembly.
Although giving cannot ultimately sever afflictions, it can eliminate and destroy present afflictions.
Because of the causes and conditions of giving, he is always praised by sentient beings in the worlds of the ten directions, innumerable and boundless like the sands of the Ganges River.
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give food to sentient beings, they give them life. Because of this retribution, when they attain Buddhahood, they are always unchanging.
Because of giving happiness, when they attain Buddhahood, they attain peace and happiness.
When bodhisattvas give, they seek wealth in accordance with the Dharma, without harming others to give to this one. Therefore, when they attain Buddhahood, they attain pure nirvÄá¹‡a.
When bodhisattvas give, they cause sentient beings to obtain without seeking. Therefore, when they attain Buddhahood, they attain mastery.
I cause others to obtain strength through the causes and conditions of giving. Therefore, when I attain Buddhahood, I will obtain the ten powers.
I cause others to obtain speech through the causes and conditions of giving. Therefore, when I attain Buddhahood, I will obtain the four unobstructed [abilities].
The buddhas and bodhisattvas cultivate this giving as a cause for nirvÄá¹‡a. I also cultivate giving in the same way as a cause for nirvÄá¹‡a.
As extensively explained in the Miscellaneous Flowers.
What is mindfulness of the gods?
There are the abodes of the Four Heavenly Kings, up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
If there is faith, and one attains the abodes of the Four Heavenly Kings, I also have a share.

If through precepts, much learning, generosity, and wisdom, one attains the abodes of the Four Heavenly Kings, up to attaining the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, I also have a share;
but this is not what I desire.
Why is it so?

Because the abodes of the Four Heavenly Kings, up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, are all impermanent. Because of impermanence, there is birth, old age, sickness, and death. For this reason, they are not what I desire.
It is like an illusion, deceiving the ignorant;
the wise are not deluded or attached to it.
The illusory is the abodes of the Four Heavenly Kings, up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
The ignorant are all ordinary beings. I am not the same as the foolish ordinary beings.

I have heard that there is a supreme truth heaven, which refers to the buddhas and bodhisattvas who are eternally unchanging. Because they abide eternally, they do not give rise to, age, fall ill, or die. I diligently seek the supreme truth heaven for the sake of sentient beings.
Why is this?
The supreme truth heaven can enable sentient beings to eliminate afflictions, just like a wish-fulfilling tree.
If I have faith and wisdom, then I will be able to attain this supreme truth heaven and will extensively expound and explain the supreme truth heaven for the sake of sentient beings.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's mindfulness of the heavens.
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva who is not of the world. This is what the world does not know, see, or perceive, but the bodhisattva knows, sees, and perceives.
Good man!

If my disciples say that upholding, reciting, copying, and expounding the twelve divisions of the canon, as well as upholding, reciting, copying, expounding, and explaining the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, are no different, that is not so.
Why is it so?
Good man!
The MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a is the profound secret treasury of all Buddhas, World-Honored Ones. Because it is the profound secret treasury of the Buddhas, it is superior.
Good man!
For this reason, the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra is extremely marvelous, extremely special, and inconceivable.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

I also know that the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra is extremely marvelous, extremely special, and inconceivable. The Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha are inconceivable, and the bodhi and great parinirvÄá¹‡a of bodhisattvas are also inconceivable.
World-Honored One!
For what meaning do you also say that bodhisattvas are inconceivable?
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have no one to teach them, yet they can give rise to the mind of enlightenment on their own. Having given rise to the mind, they diligently cultivate and practice.
Even if a great fire burns their bodies and heads, they will never seek to be saved, abandoning the mind of mindfulness of the Dharma.
Why is this?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always reflect:

'For immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, I have either been in the hells, hungry ghosts, animals, human realm, or heavenly realm, being burned by the fires of the afflictions, never having attained a definitive Dharma before.
The definitive Dharma is precisely anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
If it is for anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, I will never spare my body, mind, or life.
